security: Releasing names of employees, particularly those who retired under cover, could expose sensitive information about past operations and potentially endanger the individuals and compromise ongoing cover operations. "THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE OF THE RELATIONSHIP OF YOUR TRUE NAME AND THE AGENCY WILL HAVE TO BE LOOKED AT CAREFULLY TO DETERMINE THE VIABILITY OF CONTINUED COVER PROTECTION."
summary: A cable from the CIA requesting assistance in contacting a former employee residing in Trieste to inform them that their name appears in documents being reviewed for release under the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992 and to offer them the opportunity to request redaction if they believe their safety or sensitive activities could be compromised.
summary_one_paragraph: This SECRET cable, dated March 5, 1997, originates from the CIA's STAFF and is addressed to the MILAN and ROME stations, requesting their assistance in contacting a former employee, residing in Trieste, who retired under cover. The purpose is to inform the individual that their name is present in documents under review for public release according to the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992. The communication includes a tear-line containing a letter to be delivered, explaining the Act's provisions, the potential for name redaction if a credible threat can be demonstrated, and contact information for Beth Mills to discuss concerns. The cable also provides answers to frequently asked questions regarding the implications of name release and potential impact on cover status.
title: Request for Station Assistance
